ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned an overview of Buddhist religious and visual tradition.
I learned a lot about Buddhist artwork and how to interpret art in general.
I learned about some of the iconography behind Buddhist art and how to perform formal analysis on Buddhist art.

I developed a strong understanding of the history, development, and breadth of Buddhist art and architecture, as well as familiarity with some of the major motifs of Buddhist art and how they vary across time and space.
Buddhist artworks, the Buddhist religion overall, and how to understand and analyze artworks in general
I learned a lot about Buddhist art and architecture.

Provides an overview of Buddhist art and architecture, spanning different geographical areas, Buddhist traditions and periods of history. Special emphasis on the religious/spiritual ideas that are expressed in the art.
A fundamental understanding of Buddhism and its three branches as well as its artistic representations in Southeast, South and East Asia.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: One thing I learned in this class was that Buddhism is really really complicated. Sometimes I wish the course slowed down a little bit to establish the foundations of the religion really clearly before diving into complicated imagery. A lot of times I felt really overwhelmed during lecture by the amount of information. Also it would be helpful if readings were posted as files rather than on course reserves. They were hard to access at times.
I thought the material was very interesting, and section was very interactive.
The professor is great
I believe the class is good the way it currently is.
Fantastic section discussions, laidback and knowledgeable instructor, well-selected readings, generally a great course.

The material is very interesting and I am glad I took the class. It was great to learn more about a religion and culture I had no exposure with prior to the class. Sometimes however, the lectures can feel a bit slow and hard to keep up with.
The course was very straightforward but got very monotonous at times.
Frequent gallery visits were a major strength and provided an excellent opportunity to engage with course material.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes I would recommend this course if you are interested in learning about Buddhist art history.
Yes take this class, the lectures are interesting and not complicated. The time commitment for this class is fairly low and it is not hard to do well in this class.

Yes - if you have the background or interest in Buddhism and would like to learn more about Buddhist art and architecture. If you are completely unfamiliar with Buddhism, this might not be the course for you - for example, many of the lectures and discussions focus on analyzing particular works and identifying deities and characters depicted. That said, the class was at least 50% art analysis, which I had very little background in, so you can probably make it work.

Yes. I found the material interesting and felt the class wasn't very difficult. There were just a few papers and 2 exams that consisted of memorizing information about a master list of images and a small essay so it isn't hard to do well in the class.
It's a solid course if you're interested in the content.
I would recommend this course.
Yes! It's a great foundation class for art history majors.
